name: 1936 Stout Scarab
description: The 1936 Stout Scarab was an upscale proto-mini van. It kept passengers comfortable and their flatware in place with a cushy four-wheel independent suspension.

name: Chrysler (Ghia) Streamline X
description: Designers originally intended to fit the 1955 Chrysler (Ghia) Streamline X "Gilda" with a gas turbine engine, but gave it a conventional motor instead.

name: 1948 Tasco
description: If the 1948 Tasco looks familiar, it’s because the lines on this car came from Gordon Buehrig, a design alumnus of Duesenberg.

name: GM Le Sabre
description: The 1951 GM Le Sabre was the first car to sport fins and a wraparound windshield, design elements that became standard in American cars thereafter.

name: 1941 Chrysler Thunderbolt
description: The curves on the 1941 Chrysler Thunderbolt were inspired by streamliner trains.

name: Buick Centurion
description: The 1956 Buick Centurion had a back-up camera decades before they appeared in consumer vehicles.

name: Cadillac Cyclone
description: The 1959 Cadillac Cyclone could drive itself using a sensor that guided it along a wire embedded in the road.

name: Voisin C-25 Aerodyne
description: The 1934 Voisin C-25 Aerodyne was a French saloon than ran on a 3.0-liter inline-6 engine that produced just over 100 horsepower.
